passages.text: Turbulent French politics. Another French prime minister is facing a decisive vote: François Bayrou announced a confidence vote on his government to be held on September 8. The reason was disagreement over the fiscal budget and how to plug the substantial public deficit. Fears mounted over a potential government collapse and potential implications for fiscal policy, following tax hikes of recent years. As a result, share prices of French companies came under renewed pressure, including our coverage (Vinci, Eiffage, AdP, Getlink, Saint Gobain). Political uncertainty is likely to last at least until early- October.

How could French companies be impacted? Higher taxation is the elephant in the room. Recent tax increases are deemed to be insufficient to permanently reduce the large government deficit. In addition, cuts to government spending (i.e., for infrastructure projects) could be implemented. A weakened or transitional government could also delay money flows and tender processes, which would impact infrastructure project approvals. Increased country risk premia due to elevated political risk levels. Lastly, significant cuts to government spending could provide cause for social unrest and disruption to public infrastructure and transport networks. Infrastructure operators, such as Vinci, Eiffage, AdP and Getlink are particularly exposed to that.

Our bear case analysis: assuming the worst. In order to determine the potential impact on our coverage, we assume several measures that could be implemented as part of the fiscal budget. This includes a permanent corporate tax increase to \(36.1\%\) , an increase to the long- distance transport infrastructure tax (to \(9.2\%\) of revenues), and an increase in the WACC by 100bps. Investors should see this as the valuation floor - the worst outcome.

Our take: markets are overpricing the downside. Our bear case analysis shows that the recent sell- off in French stocks is overpriced. The downside to most stocks appears modest, especially relative to the upside. In addition, if political noise does not materialize (i.e., no material shift in taxation or infrastructure policy), upside is even larger, and the current price levels present an excellent buying opportunity. This would be similar to what was seen at the end of August 2024, when political uncertainty caused a correction in French share price levels, which later reversed as stability returned. We advise caution around AdP and see the stock as fairly priced at current levels, with more substantially more downside if taxation should materialize.

Significant upside for Vinci and Eiffage. Both Vinci and Eiffage have sizable operations in France (Vinci: \(51\%\) of EBIT; Eiffage: \(86\%\) ). Domestic trends thus matter for growth prospects and valuation. Our bear case analysis suggests significant upside after the recent substantial share price decline: for Vinci, we see the valuation floor at €127.7 per share as fair - c. \(- 13\%\) below our current TP. For Eiffage, we think a floor at €125.3 per share - c. \(- 21\%\) below our current TP.

Political uncertainty prevails in France... Following French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou's announcement of a confidence vote on his government to be held on 8 September, the share prices of French infrastructure and building materials came under renewed pressure. Fears mounted over a potential government collapse and potential implications for fiscal policy, following tax hikes of recent years. The cause for the confidence vote was the disagreement over the government's budget proposal, which foresees austerity measures worth €44bn. In case of Bayrou's loss of the confidence vote, which we esteem as being very likely, uncertainty will persist until early October, in our view, when the fiscal budget must be submitted by the Macron administration.

...And sees shares prices slump across our coverage. As a result of heightened political uncertainty, we have seen substantial share price declines across our coverage. While the CAC 40 Index fell c.3%, share prices of Eiffage and Vinci, the largest French infrastructure companies, slumped by - 15% and - 9% respectively. Airport operator AdP was also under pressure, falling by more than - 8%. Building materials company Saint Gobain and Eurotunnel operator Getlink saw more benign declines, at c. - 4.6%. These companies are less exposed to additional taxation on infrastructure assets. Especially Getlink is structurally more insulated from unilateral domestic policy changes by either France or the UK.

How are French corporates impacted? We identified several channels that could impact French corporates. Higher taxation is the elephant in the room. Recent tax increases are deemed to be insufficient to permanently reduce the large government deficit. A structural increase in the tax burden is the likeliest outcome for French corporates. In addition, cuts to government spending, especially funds flowing to infrastructure projects, could be taken. A weakened or transitional government could also delay spending and tender processes, which would impact infrastructure project approvals. On a structural level, an increased risk premium due to elevated risk levels and the widening of government bond spreads would impact valuation, especially for infrastructure companies. Lastly, significant cuts to government spending could provide cause for social unrest and disruption to public infrastructure and transport networks. Infrastructure operators, such as Vinci, Eiffage, AdP and Getlink are particularly exposed to that.
What matters for infrastructure companies? Breaking down the impact channels, we identified three risk factors for our infrastructure coverage that investors should be wary of.

1. Increase in corporate tax. The extension of the temporary corporate tax increase due in 2025 for French corporates is a likely measure to reduce the government budget deficit. In our bear case, we assume the 2025 temporary tax increase becomes permanent, with firms with revenues above €3bn required to pay an average tax rate of 36.1%, an increase of 40%+ compared to the standard rate.

2. Changes to concession contracts. Although the French concession framework is benign, political interventions do happen, and we currently perceive the risk of an increase in infrastructure-specific taxation as elevated. In our bear case, we assume a two-fold increase in the long-distance transport infrastructure tax (we call it TEILD 2.0) to 9.2%. However, it is important to note that France's concession framework allows infrastructure companies to appeal any legislative unilateral concession contract changes, such as Vinci and Eiffage did with TEILD (1.0).

3. Nationalization of infrastructure assets. The French commission framework stipulates that the government is allowed to buy back any concession for reasons of public interest, subject to a one-year notice period. Although the high compensation payments are likely to deter any future government from exercising the buyback option, certain politicians have already announced their ambition to nationalize certain assets. This could impact our coverage negatively, especially when the buyback payments are lower than expected. In our bear case, we assume an increase in the WACC by 100bps to account for this and the risks that political uncertainty entails.

Our bear case analysis: is the downside overpriced? Yes, downside appears overpriced. Our bear case analysis has shown that the recent sell-off in French stocks is overpriced. The downside to most stocks appears modest, especially relative to the upside. In addition, if political noise does not materialize (i.e., no material shift in taxation or infrastructure policy), upside is even larger, and the current price levels present an excellent buying opportunity for Vinci and Eiffage. This would be similar to what was seen at the end of August 2024, when political uncertainty caused a correction in French share price levels, which later reversed as stability returned. We advise caution around AdP and see the stock as fairly priced at current levels, with more substantially more downside if taxation should materialize.

- Significant upside for Vinci and Eiffage... Despite the internationalization of the business in over the last decades, both Vinci and Eiffage have sizable operations in France. Vinci generates around \(42\%\) of sales and \(51\%\) of EBIT in the country, while Eiffage does \(66\%\) and \(86\%\) , respectively. As a result, the understanding of domestic trends continue to play a vital role in understanding the companies' values and growth prospects. Our bear case analysis, in which we assume the above-outlined impacts at once, suggests significant upside after the recent substantial share price decline. For Vinci, our bear case analysis suggests a valuation floor of €127.7 per share - some \(9\%\) above current share price levels and c.- \(13\%\) below our current SOTP valuation. For Eiffage, we see the valuation floor at €125.3 per share - some \(17\%\) above current share price levels and - \(21.1\%\) below our current SOTP valuation.

- ...While AdP has room to fall further. AdP generates around \(70\%\) of its sales in France, predominantly at its three airports in Paris. The group is partly shielded from an increase in the long-distance infrastructure tax, as it can recoup \(75\%\) of the elevated expenses through higher aeronautical tariffs. Broad corporate tax increases, however, would have a more direct earnings impact. Therefore, our bear case analysis suggests AdP's valuation floor to be at €104 per share - some \(8\%\) below current share price levels and our current SOTP valuation.

- GetLink is shielded from adverse impacts... In contrast to Vinci, Eiffage and AdP, Getlink has been less impacted by the political uncertainty in France. This is due to changes to its regulatory framework requiring approval from both France and the UK, thereby reducing the exposure to unilateral fiscal or regulatory intervention. Given the bilateral overview of Getlink's operations, there is limited risk of an increase in taxation to the group. In our view, the key risk is anchored in the increase of French government bond yields, which would impact Getlink's WACC and thus valuation: assuming a 100bps increase, we see the floor of Getlink's fair value at €13.81 per share - some \(15\%\) below current share price levels and - \(19\%\) below our current SOTP valuation.

- ...While Saint Gobain would suffer from a corporate tax hike. The direct impact on Saint Gobain would come in the form of higher taxation, which would be hard to pass on to consumers via pricing increases given the softness of the French construction market. France has been the weakest market in Europe and the recovery is getting delayed; Saint Gobain have been saying since Q4'24 that the French market has troughed. However, 3 quarters have passed since, and we are still in the trough, with no recovery in sight. The political uncertainty and higher taxes could lead to further weakening of the French construction volumes and pricing could get tougher in the worst case. However, these impacts are expected to be rather limited to Saint Gobain's fair valuation, and we maintain our MP rating and PT of €100/share, going into the CMD on 6th Oct.

For a more in- depth analysis of the current situation in France, we recommend reading the report by SG economists "France - So many paths to political gridlock" (26 August; link).

What happened? On Monday, French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou announced a confidence vote on his government (to be held on September 8). The vote is centered around approval for the 2026 fiscal budget, which aims reducing France's soaring public debt. As a result, the share prices of French stocks have recently slumped, while bond spreads widened. Bayrou's budget proposal includes a few controversial points: a) €44bn in spending cuts, including freezes on pensions and social welfare programs; b) elevated tax brackets at 2025 levels; c) further reductions in government spending to reduce the large deficit 5.8% GDP in 2024; and d) reduction of the ballooning public debt (113% of GDP; among the highest in the EU).

The context. The roots of the current political uncertainty in France lay deeper: in June 2024, President Macro dissolved the French parliament to call a snap election in response to the crushing defeat for his party during the European Parliament elections. The election resulted in a parliament without an outright majority for any political bloc.

What is next? With no parliamentary majority, Bayrou's government now teeters on the edge of collapse, which raises questions about the future of Macron's administration. This also cloud the outlook on France's fiscal stability, given the grand investment ambitions by opposition parties. So far, most parties outside Bayrou's government (including National Rally, France Unbowed, the Greens, and the Socialists) have declared to vote against Bayrou on September 8. This renders the risk of defeat high - which would force Bayrou to resign. As a reminder, this would mirror the fate of former Prime Minister Mr Michel Barnier, who was ousted after just 90 days in office when the parliament rejected his 2025 budget. Our view is that Bayrou's government is likely fall on 8 September, given low approval ratings and the stark fragmentation along political lines of the parliament.
Macron's options after the potential Bayrou defeat. If and when Bayrou loses the confidence vote, Macron can choose from three main options:

1. Keep Bayrou in office as a caretaker leader until a new government can be formed.  
2. Appoint a new prime minister (a difficult task given the fragmented parliament).  
3. Call new elections, risking further instability and potential gains by left and rightwing parties.

Uncertainty is likely to persist until early October. We expect uncertainty to last until early October if and when Bayrou loses the confidence vote. Macron is unlikely to take a swift decision and might even try to gauge whether a compromise between centrist and Socialist parties is agreeable. In October, however, a decision must be taken: a fiscal budget draft must be presented in parliament, so Macron will either have to name a new prime minister to present the draft or call for early elections. In case new elections are announced by Macron, they are likely to take place between end- October and mid- November (the first round must happen between 20 and 40 days post- announcement). The earliest a new prime minister would assume office is by end- November, with little time to pass the fiscal budget. As was the case last year, it is likely the 2025 budget will be prolonged for a few weeks in 2026 before a proper budget law is passed.

Four channels that impact French corporates. The political uncertainty in France has already impacted both bond yields and share prices of French entities. We have identified four separate channels that are the reason for the impact on our coverage - and continue to be causes of concern:

- Reduced spending and higher taxation. The risk of higher taxation is the elephant in the room. Recent tax increases, including the temporary corporate tax hike and introduction of the long-distance infrastructure tax, are deemed to be insufficient to permanently reduce the large government deficit. Hence, the elevation of the tax burden for French corporates is likely through the adoption of the next fiscal budget. In addition, austerity measures could reduce state-backed infrastructure spending.
- Policy paralysis and investment delays. A weakened or transitional government could delay government spending and tender processes. This would impact infrastructure project approvals.

- Increased risk premium. Political instability could lead to higher risk premia for French entities through the widening of government bond yields. Especially infrastructure assets, both in equity and credit markets, are impacted, given the relevance of the risk premia in evaluating them. The heightened political uncertainty doesn't bode well for the string of credit-rating reviews starting in September. With Fitch due to review on Sept. 12, a government collapse would pose a real risk of a reassessment;

- Elevated risk of social unrest. The adoption of a budget that cuts too much into the muscle of government spending could see protest-prone French citizens take to the streets. The confidence vote will take place just two days before nationwide protests organized by leftwing groups and certain unions. The extent of the protests is likened to the 2018 Yellow Vest movement, which erupted over rising living costs and caused significant disruption to public infrastructure and transport networks. Infrastructure operators, such as Vinci, AdP and Getlink are particularly exposed to that.

The impact on our coverage. Since 22 August, we have seen substantial share price declines across our coverage. While the CAC 40 Index fell c. \(3\%\) , share prices of Eiffage and Vinci, the largest French infrastructure companies, slumped by - 15 and - \(9\%\) respectively. Airport operator AdP was also under pressure, falling by c. \(- 8\%\) . Building materials company Saint Gobain and Eurotunnel operator Getlink saw more benign declines, at c. \(- 4.6\%\) . These companies are less exposed to additional taxation on infrastructure assets. Especially Getlink is structurally more insulated from unilateral domestic policy changes by either France or the UK.

Breaking down the four impact channels, we identified the following risk factors for our coverage that investors be wary of:

1. Increase in corporate tax. The extension of the temporary corporate tax increase due in 2025 for French corporates is a likely measure to reduce the government's budget deficit. As a reminder, the tax is applied to all companies based in France, and determined based on the average revenues of 2024 and 2025. Firms with revenues below €3bn are required to pay an average tax rate of \(30.15\%\) , compared to the standard rate of \(25\%\) ( \(20\% +\) additional tax burden). Firms with revenues above €3bn are required to pay an average tax rate of \(36.1\%\) , which constitutes an increase of \(40\% +\) compared to the standard rate. In our bear case, we assume the 2025 temporary tax increase to be permanent.

2. Changes to concession contracts. In general, our perception of the French concession framework is benign, with tested principles of full or partial compensation in the event of unilateral changes (i.e., by either side of the agreement) to the concession agreements. However, political interventions, such as the recent implementation of a \(4.6\%\) tax on revenues of long-distance transport infrastructure assets, do happen. We currently perceive the risk of an increase in infrastructure-specific taxation as elevated. In our bear case, we assume a two-fold increase in the long-distance transport infrastructure tax (we call it TEILD 2.0) to \(9.2\%\) . However, it is important to note that France's concession framework allows infrastructure companies to appeal any unilateral contract legislative changes, such as Vinci and Eiffage did with TEILD.

3. Nationalization of infrastructure assets. The French concession framework stipulates that the government is allowed to buy back any concession for reasons of public interest, subject to a one-year notice period. If exercised, the concessionaire is entitled to compensation in line with the loss suffered through the contract's termination, which is calculated as the estimated fair value of the concession based on the net present value of future cash flows. Although the high compensation payments are likely to deter any future government from exercising the buyback option, certain politicians have already announced their ambition to nationalize certain assets. This could impact our coverage negatively, especially when the buyback payments are lower than expected. In our bear case, we assume an increase in the WACC by 100bps to account for this and the risks that political uncertainty entails.

Little judicial leeway. Vinci and Eiffage appealed the TEILD after it was announced in 2023, in accordance with their contractual rights. However, in September 2024, the French Constitutional Council ruled that the TEILD was compliant with the French Constitution and thus remains in place. As a response, the infrastructure companies filed contractual compensation claims with the relevant French entity by requesting the triggering of the tax neutrality clauses in the concession agreements. A decision is not expected over the next few years, and we would an appeal against potential new taxation of infrastructure assets to be equally onerous.

The key question after the announcement of the upcoming confidence vote is whether the recent share price decline across our coverage are justified. We think that especially Vinci and Eiffage have been punished in an unjustly harsh way, while AdP could fall further. To test our hypothesis, we assume a permanent increase in corporate tax to \(36.125\%\) and the levy of an additional long- distance infrastructure tax (from \(4.6\%\) to \(9.2\%\) ). We also assume a 100bps structural increase in the WACC to account for elevated political risk in France, and complement this by company- specific measures, such as a reduction in the fair value of individual business segments.

- Significant upside for Vinci and Eiffage... Despite the internationalization of the business in over the last decades, both Vinci and Eiffage have sizable operations in France. Vinci generates around \(42\%\) of sales and \(51\%\) of EBIT in the country, while Eiffage does \(66\%\) and \(86\%\) , respectively. As a result, the understanding of domestic trends continue to play a vital role in understanding the companies' values and growth prospects. Our bear case analysis, in which we assume the above-outlined impacts at once, suggests significant upside after the recent substantial share price decline. For Vinci, our bear case analysis suggests a valuation floor of €127.7 per share - some \(9\%\) above current share price levels and c.- \(13\%\) below our current SOTP valuation. For Eiffage, we see the valuation floor at €125.3 per share - some \(17\%\) above current share price levels and - \(21.1\%\) below our current SOTP valuation.

- ...While AdP has room to fall further. AdP generates around \(70\%\) of its sales in France, predominantly at its three airports in Paris. The group is partly shielded from an increase in the long-distance infrastructure tax, as it can recoup \(75\%\) of the elevated expenses through higher aeronautical tariffs. Broad corporate tax increases, however, would have a more direct earnings impact. Therefore, our bear case analysis suggests AdP's valuation floor to be at €104 per share - some \(8\%\) below current share price levels and our current SOTP valuation.

- GetLink is shielded from adverse impacts... In contrast to Vinci, Eiffage and AdP, GetLink has been less impacted by the political uncertainty in France. This is due to changes to its regulatory framework requiring approval from both France and the UK, thereby reducing the exposure to unilateral fiscal or regulatory intervention. Given the bilateral overview of GetLink's operations, there is limited risk of an increase in taxation to the group. In our view, the key risk is anchored in the increase of French government bond yields, which would impact GetLink's WACC and thus valuation: assuming a 100bps increase, we see the floor of GetLink's fair value at €13.81 per share - some \(15\%\) below current share price levels and - \(19\%\) below our current SOTP valuation.

- ...While Saint Gobain would suffer from a corporate tax hike. The direct impact on Saint Gobain would come in the form of higher taxation, which would be hard to pass on to consumers via pricing increases given the softness of the French construction market. France has been the weakest market in Europe and the recovery is getting delayed; Saint Gobain have been saying since Q4'24 that the French market has troughed. However, 3 quarters have passed since, and we are still in the trough, with no recovery in sight. The political uncertainty and higher taxes could lead to further weakening of the French construction volumes and pricing could get tougher in the worst case. However, these impacts are expected to be rather limited to Saint Gobain's fair valuation, and we maintain our MP rating and PT of €100/share, going into the CMD on 6th Oct.

Yes, downside appears overpriced. Our bear case analysis has shown that the recent sell- off in French stocks is overpriced. The downside to most stocks appears modest, especially relative to the upside. In addition, if political noise does not materialize (i.e., no material shift in taxation or infrastructure policy), upside is even larger, and the current price levels present an excellent buying opportunity for Vinci and Eiffage. This would be similar to what was seen at the end of August 2024, when political uncertainty caused a correction in French share price levels, which later reversed as stability returned. We advise caution around AdP and see the stock as fairly priced at current levels, with more substantially more downside if taxation should materialize.

Despite the internationalization of Vinci's businesses, the group's financials are still heavily exposed to France, with \(42\%\) of sales, \(51\%\) of EBIT, and nearly \(60\%\) of free cash flow (all FY'24 numbers). Especially the Autoroutes segment, with its French toll road concessions, is inherently French ( \(9.2\%\) of sales, \(36\%\) of EBIT, and \(37\%\) of free cash flows exposed to France) and most exposed to potential new taxation efforts by the French government. As a result, the understanding of domestic trends continue to play a vital role in understanding Vinci's value and growth prospects. In our SOTP valuation framework, we estimate that France accounts for c. \(39\%\) of the company's overall net asset value. This already factors in a conservative approach concerning future taxation, including a permanent €200m higher tax from FY '26 onward (s. Vinci: All eyes on the French political picture for more detail).

Our bear case analysis. Applying the permanently higher tax rate \((36.125\%)\) and the two- fold increase in the long- distance infrastructure tax, we estimate an average impact of c. \(- 7.7\%\) on Vinci's financials. Complementing this by the 100bps increase in the WACC and a Vinci- specific \(15\%\) reduction of the targeted contracting enterprise value (excluding Cobra- IS), we see the floor of Vinci's fair value at €127.7, which translates into a - \(13.1\%\) gap to our current SOTP valuation.

The territorial economic contribution (Contribution Economique Territoriale or CET) is a local tax levied by municipal, departmental and regional councils on businesses to help fund local services and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The CET consists of two components: the Cotisation Fonciere des Entreprises (CFE) and the Cotisation sur la Valeur Ajoutee des Entreprises (CVAE)

The 2023 Finance Law cut CVAE tax rates by \(50\%\) and planned full abolition in 2024. The 2024 Finance Law revised this to a gradual phase-out over four years, ending in 2027. The 2025 Finance Law further altered this approach, now implementing a three-year phase-out starting in 2028, with full abolition scheduled for 2030

The French Tax Code requires motorway companies to pay a tax based on the number of kilometers driven by motorway user Recent legal changes have adjusted this tax to be indexed to inflation. Starting on 1 January 2022, the tax indexation is set at \(70\%\) of the change in the CPI (exe. tobacco) for the month of November, comparing the second year before the revision to the year immediately prior to the revision

For 2024, the tax rate is 68.02 per 1,000 km, and for 2025, it will be 68.08 per 1,000 km APRR is seeking compensation for the increase in TAT. Litigation with the French State is currently ongoing, with an outcome anticipated in H1 2025
The TAT is deductible for corporate income tax determination

Starting 1 January 2024, a new tax was introduced for companies operating long-distance transport infrastructure. This tax applies to companies with annual revenues exceeding 120m and a historical profit margin over \(10\%\) in the last seven years. The tax is \(4.6\%\) of the annual revenues that exceed 120m per legal entity and is not deductible for corporate income tax purposes

APRR (alongside other affected toll road companies) has adopted a two-step approach to contest this tax. The first step involves a judicial review for an abuse of power before the French Council of State, which led to a challenge of the constitutionality of the tax before the French Constitutional Council. In September 2024, the Constitutional Council ruled that the new tax complies with the French Constitution. The ruling for the judicial review is expected in 2025. If this approach fails, APRR is proposing to file a contractual compensation claim against the French State and is considering other avenues of recourse in parallel. This legal process is expected to take several years to resolve

Similar to Vinci and Eiffage, the French airport operator AdP, which runs three airports in Paris (Charles de Gaulle, Orly and Le Bourget), is also exposed to regulatory uncertainty and an emerging risk of higher corporate taxation. The group's sales are to \(c.70\%\) exposed to France. Especially infrastructure companies could be a key focus of unique taxation schemes, as they have been in recent years. In order to understand what the potential increase in taxation could entail for AdP's financials, it is important to revisit the recent tax changes:

Long- distance infrastructure tax (TEILD). This tax scheme was introduced in 2024. It stipulates the payment of \(4.6\%\) tax applicable to total revenue, excluding revenues from airport safety and security services, and after the deduction of a €120m exemption. In addition, AdP is allowed to recoup \(75\%\) of the tax through future increases of aeronautical tariffs (i.e., over two to three years), in accordance with the regulatory principle of moderate annual changes to tariffs that is guiding AdP's regulatory framework. Thus, the group has to shoulder only \(25\%\) of the actual tax increase. AdP's management estimated the impact to be around c. €130m to €140m p.a. in additional operating costs through the payment of higher operational taxes. In 2024, this translated to c. \(2\%\) of total revenue.

Temporary corporate tax increase. In 2024, the French government introduced a temporary corporate tax increase for large corporations, which stipulates a surtax of \(41.2\%\) paid in 2025 if total annual revenue exceeds €3bn. This would increase the effective tax rate to \(36.125\%\) . AdP's management estimated the impact to be around c. €110m to €120m, of which €64m was already paid in H1 '25. In contrast to the long- distance infrastructure tax, there is no pass through mechanism to adjust for this tax increase.

To calculate the potential financial impact for AdP if new taxation was to be levied, we draw up two scenarios which we compare against our blue sky case (i.e., no additional taxation).

- Scenario 1: increase the long-distance infrastructure tax to \(9.2\%\) . For the first scenario, we assume a permanent increase of the long-distance infrastructure tax to \(9.2\%\) , from currently \(4.6\%\) . This translates into an increase in operating costs of \(4.3\%\) of AdP's revenue, compared to \(2.1\%\) in our current assumptions. The resulting impact would be an average decline of AdP's EPS in excess of \(-12.0\%\) into perpetuity.

- Scenario 2: extend the temporary tax increase. For the second scenario, we assume that the temporary corporate tax increase in 2025 is extended permanently. This translates into an average effective tax rate of \(36.125\%\) , compared to \(24\%\) in our current forecasts. The resulting impact would be an average decline of AdP's EPS in excess of \(-15\%\) .

Our bear case analysis. Applying the permanently higher tax rate \((36.125\%)\) and the two- fold increase in the long- distance infrastructure tax, we estimate an average impact of c. \(-26.2\%\) on AdP's financials. Complementing this by the 100bps increase in the WACC, we see the floor of AdP's fair value at €104.0, which translates into a \(-8.8\%\) gap to our current SOTP valuation. Investors should keep in mind that ADP's vulnerability to tax hikes is highly contingent on the tax design. If the government opts for targeted infrastructure levies, ADP's regulated model provides insulation. In contrast, broad corporate tax increases would likely have a more direct earnings impact.

GETLINK: POLITICAL INSULATION TO THE RESCUEIn contrast to Vinci, Eiffage and AdP, Getlink, which operates the Eurotunnel through a long- term concession, has been less impacted by the political uncertainty in France. This is owed to the fact that changes to the concession agreement require approval from both France and the UK, thereby reducing the exposure to unilateral fiscal or regulatory intervention. While companies like Vinci and Eiffage derive a significant portion of revenue from the domestic market, Getlink is inherently international, tied to cross- Channel transportation flows between the UK and continental Europe.

Our bear case analysis. Given the bilateral overview of Getlink's operations, there is limited risk of an increase in taxation to the group. In our view, the key risk is anchored in the increase of French government bond yields, which would impact Getlink's WACC and thus valuation: assuming a 100bps increase, we see the floor of Getlink's fair value at €13.81 per share, which translates into a \(- 19\%\) gap to our current valuation.

The primary direct impact on Saint Gobain comes through the higher taxation on French profits. However, there could be secondary impacts on Saint Gobain in terms of a prolonged weakness in the French construction market, and worsening pricing power. A further impact could come from investors assigning higher risk premia resulting in higher WACCs for French stocks.

Tax impact: Saint Gobain derives \(\sim 24\%\) of its sales or \(>10bn\) of revenues from France (see Exhibit 36). So, Saint Gobain's profits in France will be taxed under the higher \(35.3\%\) tax rate. Last year when the higher taxes were implemented, Saint Gobain had highlighted that the impact of these higher taxes were rather low, because Saint Gobain also has quite high costs. As a result operating profit from France is \(EXHIBIT 36: Saint Gobain geographic exposure
Source: Company data, Bernstein analysis and estimates

Impact on organic growth: France has been the weakest market for construction in Europe (see Exhibit 39). Most companies in our coverage have been highlighting that French volumes are still reducing and do not expect a recovery before next year. Saint Gobain is closest to the French market, especially due to their distribution arm, which is by far the largest building products distribution company in France (6x larger than the \(2^{nd}\) peer). Saint Gobain have been saying since \(Q4^{'}\) 24 that the French market has troughed. However, it's been 3 quarters since and Saint Gobain are still saying that France is at the trough, while there is no longer any decline in Saint Gobain's French volumes, they are also not seeing any recovery yet. At the Q2 results, Saint Gobain said they were hoping to see a recovery by year end (Link). However, with higher taxes, more uncertainty with the government in turmoil, the construction sector might continue to weak or weaken over the coming quarters.

In our published model, we have assumed French volume growth/decline of \(- 3\%\) in FY25, \(0.6\%\) in FY26, \(1.6\%\) in FY27 and \(- 0.3\%\) in FY28. If we assume a flat \(1\%\) lower growth in France over the forecast period (starting in Q3'25, see Exhibit 37), it leads to \(\sim 1\%\) or €1 reduction to our PT of €100/share.

Further, the weaker market might result in lower pricing power in France. In our, published model, we assume French pricing growth/decline of \(- 0.9\%\) in FY25, \(0.5\%\) in FY26, \(1.0\%\) in FY27 and \(1.5\%\) in FY28. If we assume a flat \(1\%\) lower pricing in France over the forecast period (starting in Q3'25, see Exhibit 38), it leads to \(\sim 1\%\) or €1 reduction to our PT of €100/share.

Impact from higher risk premium: We have seen a mass exodus from French equity this week, since the confidence vote announcement. Given the political risk in France, investors might be assigning high risk premia to French stocks. Raising the equity risk premium and WACC by \(\sim 1\%\) , leads to €17 reduction to our PT. (see Exhibit 40)

Major upcoming catalyst: Saint Gobain will host their CMD on \(6^{\text{th}}\) Oct. We believe this will be a major catalyst. Saint Gobain has their previous CMD in 2021, and they have met all of their 2025 target already by 2024. So at present, we do not have any medium term guidance for the company.

We see Saint Gobain as fairly valued: Saint Gobain suffered a shock from the political risk on Monday, declining \(\sim 4.5\%\) on the day. While this might have been slightly overdone, we still view Saint Gobain as being fairly valued, going into the CMD in early Oct. We rate Saint Gobain MP with a PT of €100/share implying \(\sim 7\%\) potential downside to the current market price. There could be upside risk to our PT if the CMD manages to positively surprise.

We value Eiffage (€158.9 PT) using a SOTP methodology. We use a finite (no terminal value) DCF model (5.4% WACC) to value Eiffage's 52.5% stake in toll road operator APRR, which comprises c.24% of our SOTP- based target price. The rest of the assets (which include other concessions, the 20.55% stake in GET and contracting) are valued using different methodologies (e.g. EV/ EBITDA; target prices, equity invested multiples, DCF, transaction deals). Concessions account for c.49% of our SOTP valuation, while the rest of the assets (mainly contracting) account for 51%.

We value Vinci (€146.7 PT) using a SOTP methodology. We mainly use a finite (no terminal value) DCF model (5.4% WACC) to value Vinci's exposure to French toll road concessions, which comprises 17.2% of our SOTP- based price target. The rest of the assets (which include airports, other concessions, and contracting) are valued using different methodologies (EV/EBITDA, market prices, equity invested multiples, DCF, transaction deals). The SOTP equity NAV mix is as follows: 49.1% contracting, 27.4% airports, 17.2% domestic toll roads, 1.1% other concessions and 5.2% other assets (including corporate net cash).

We value Groupe AdP using our proprietary Sum- of- the- Parts (SOTP) valuation framework. The regulated segment in Paris, which consists mainly of the Aviation business and is complemented by specific non- aviation sources of income (i.e., rental income, car parking, industrial services), is valued through our Regulated Asset Base (RAB) and excess returns model at c. 6x FY+2 EBITDA. In this model, we forecast the level of tariff increases and apply a discount or premium based on the expected performance relative to the regulatory WACC. The non- regulated segment in Paris, encompassing the Retail, Real Estate, and Telecommunication businesses, is valued using various valuation methods: we apply a target EV/EBITDA multiple to the retail (12x) and real estate (18x) segments and value recently acquired retail businesses at acquisition price (€360m); we also apply an EV/EBITDA multiple to AdP's Hub One business (7.5x), based on other asset- light telcoms; and we value the group's existing land reserves around its Parisian airports at fair value (€221m). AdP's international assets are valued using various valuation methods: the stake in Turkish airport operator TAV is valued at market value, to which we apply a discount to account for elevated political risk (- 15%); the stake in AIG is valued by applying a median EV/EBITDA multiple based on international airport operator peers; the stake in Indian airport operator GMR is valued through the average of its discounted market value (- 30%), our DCF analysis (WACC: 9.9%), and an adjusted EV/EBITDA multiple based on Fraport's recent disposal of its stake in Delhi airport (13.1x); and we estimate the value of AdP's other international assets. Together, our TP is €114.00.

We value Getlink (€17.1 PT) using an SOTP approach. We use a finite (no terminal value) DCF model (7.4% WACC) to value the core Fixed Link business, which comprises c.90% of our SOTP- based targeted EV value. We value the remaining assets (UK- France electricity interconnection ElecLink and the Europorte rail freight business) using different methodologies (a DCF model and EV/ EBITDA multiples).

We use a DCF methodology to derive our target price for Saint- Gobain of €100. Our WACC is \(9.4\%\) . We use a risk- free rate of \(3.3\%\) , risk premium of \(7.4\%\) , beta of 1.23 and weighted average cost of debt of \(2.0\%\) after tax. We apply a terminal growth of \(2.5\%\) .

Downside risks. 1) deterioration in credit markets and increases in real bond yields; 2) units' operational performance far below expectations; 3) M&A deals executed at high prices; and 4) new unexpected higher domestic taxes.

In our view, the main downside risks are as follows: 1) operating performance coming in significantly below expectations on weaker GDP trends and austerity measures; 2) potential M&A deals executed at high prices; 3) unexpected negative ESG newsflow; 4) unexpected political interference in core infra assets; and 5) an unexpected and significant working capital deterioration. Specifically with regard to the SOTP, we note that: 1) every \(10\%\) reduction (higher WACC, lower traffic, lower tariffs, etc.) in the domestic toll roads valuation implies a c. \(1.7\%\) reduction in our SOTP valuation; 2) a \(10\%\) reduction in our valuation of the contracting business implies a c. \(4.9\%\) reduction in our SOTP valuation; and 3) a \(10\%\) reduction in our airports valuation implies a c. \(2.7\%\) reduction in our SOTP valuation.
Key upside risks include:

- A more benign recovery in China-outbound and corporate travel to and from Paris than what has commonly been expected would be a key upside risk to our rating and TP.- We have a constructive, but conservative view on AdP's Extime Paris retail strategy. A better-than-expected performance would impact the group positively.- GMR's airports business has gone through an intense capex cycle, which dented profitability. A faster-than-expected return to profitability would challenge the discount that we have applied to the group's market value in our SOTP.
Key downside risks include:

- Groupe AdP's airports are reliant on continued air travel demand (both leisure and business travel to varying degrees). Economic crises, pandemics, terrorist attacks and other global events that impact this demand are key risks to our TP.- AdP is exposed to client concentration risk. AF-KLM has a share of \(50\% +\) at Paris-CDG and c. \(40\%\) at Paris-ORY. As a result, changes to the strategies of key airlines can negatively impact traffic.- Given the regulation of critical infrastructure assets in France, the regulator sets the tariffs that determine the topline of AdP's Aviation business. A lower-than-expected allowed return would impact the group negatively.- Restrictive environmental regulation in Europe could impact travel demand, with fewer airlines willing to fly to Paris or increased costs for airport operators. In addition, arbitrary changes to the tax regime in France can also negatively impact the group.
Risks to the upside: lower real bond yields and M&A (GET as a potential bid candidate); To the downside: units' operational performance far below expectations.

Upside risks - 1) Recovery to residential sector gets accelerated. 2) Better than expected development of macroeconomic and geopolitical factors. 3) Better than expected performance of the western auto sector.
Downside risks - 1) Recovery to residential sector gets delayed. 2) Adverse development of macroeconomic and geopolitical factors.

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
